thread.title_full: AltspaceVR Raises $10 Million, Launches Virtual Tabletop Game Space - Forbes

author: David M. Ewalt
title: AltspaceVR Raises $10 Million, Launches Virtual Tabletop Game Space
text:
Virtual reality software company AltspaceVR announced this morning that it has raised an additional $10.3 million in venture funding to grow its team and accelerate product development.
“We’re really excited to put some more money in the company,” says Eric Romo, founder and CEO of AltspaceVR. “We come to work everyday and feel like there’s so much more to do in this space… we had that conversation with our investors, and now we get to go out and hire more people.”
Participants in the funding round include return investors Tencent, Dolby Family Ventures, Raine Ventures Lux Capital, Western Technology Investments, Maven Ventures, Promus Ventures, Streamlined Ventures and Rothenberg Ventures, along with new investor Comcast Ventures. Redwood City, California-based AltspaceVR was founded in 2013, and including an initial $5.4 million round in 2014, has now raised $15.7M in total capital.
Altspace bills itself as “the social VR company,” and makes virtual reality communication software that allows people to share content and experiences in a virtual online environment. Users appear as avatars that resemble robots within a variety of different settings, ranging from high-tech cinemas to to Japanese tea gardens. Once there they can converse over voice chat, watch streaming video from services including Netflix and Twitch, and even play tabletop games against each other.
Just last week, the company unveiled its latest virtual space, a fantasy-themed tavern, along with a new application it calls V20 , a fantasy role-playing game system for virtual reality. The software provides players with a virtual battle grid, polyhedral dice, and a soundboard for dynamic music, and is compatible with tabletop RPG systems like Dungeons & Dragons.
A player considers the battle grid in AltspaceVR’s new V20 virtual role-playing game space. (Image: AltspaceVR)
The Altspace VR software launched in open beta in May 2015, and is currently available for Oculus users, Mac and PC desktops, and 3D TVs. CEO Eric Romo says the company will continue to develop and expand the software, but has no immediate plans to leave beta and launch a final commercial version.
The market for virtual reality products is currently booming in advance of several highly anticipated VR headsets due to hit stores in the coming year, including the Facebook-owned Oculus Rift , Sony’s Project Morpheus , and the Valve and HTC co-developed Vive .
